item.title: Apple Fritter Waffle Donuts
item.description: Crispy-on-the-outside, fluffy apple fritter waffle donuts made in a standard waffle maker. This recipe balances tart Granny Smith apples with warm spices and a simple glaze, taking about 30 minutes total from start to table.
item.dc:creator: author_001
item.content:encoded:

üç≥ Cook Time: 15 minutes

‚è∞ Total Time: N/A minutes

üçΩÔ∏è Servings: 6

üìä Difficulty: Medium

ü•ò Ingredients

  • 1 cup all-purpose flour
  • 2 tablespoons granulated sugar
  • 1 teaspoon baking powder
  • 1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon
  • 1/4 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg
  • 1/2 teaspoon salt
  • 1/2 cup whole milk
  • 1 large egg
  • 1/2 cup diced Granny Smith apple (about 1 medium apple)
  • 1/4 cup unsalted butter, melted
  • 1 cup powdered sugar
  • 2 tablespoons whole milk (for glaze)
  • 1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract

üë©‚Äçüç≥ Instructions

  1. Heat your waffle maker to medium-high heat (around 375¬∞F if your model displays temperature). This usually takes about 3-4 minutes. While it preheats, combine the flour, sugar, baking powder, cinnamon, nutmeg, and salt in a medium bowl, whisking them together to distribute the leavening agent evenly.
  2. In a separate bowl, crack the egg and whisk it lightly, then pour in the milk and melted butter, stirring just until combined. Pour the wet mixture into the dry ingredients and fold together using a spatula with about 12-15 folds. The batter should look shaggy with visible flour streaks‚Äîstop mixing here. Overmixing develops gluten and creates tough, dense donuts.
  3. Gently fold in the diced apples, using about 8-10 folds to distribute them throughout without crushing the fruit. If you're using apple pieces cut into 1/4-inch dice, they'll cook through in the time it takes the waffle to bake. Let the batter rest for 3 minutes while your waffle maker finishes heating.
  4. Lightly spray or brush the waffle maker grids with nonstick spray. Scoop approximately 1/3 cup batter into each compartment, filling until it reaches just below the rim. Close the lid gently and cook for 3-5 minutes, watching for steam to subside from the sides‚Äîthis signals the donuts are approaching done.
  5. Open the waffle maker carefully and check for golden brown color on the edges. If the waffle doesn't release easily when you lift the lid, close it for another 30 seconds. Tip: if your waffle maker locks down firmly, the donuts will likely need about 4-5 minutes total. More loosely hinged models may finish in 3-4 minutes.
  6. While the last batch cooks, whisk together the powdered sugar, 2 tablespoons milk, and vanilla extract in a small bowl. Stir for about 30 seconds until the glaze reaches a consistency that flows easily but still coats the back of a spoon. If it's too thick, add milk one teaspoon at a time. If too thin, sift in more powdered sugar.
  7. Transfer each finished waffle donut to a wire cooling rack set over a sheet of parchment paper. This prevents the glaze from pooling underneath and making the bottoms soggy. Once all donuts are cooked, drizzle the glaze over each one using a fork or small spoon, working relatively quickly while they're still warm so the glaze sets lightly.
